expectations:
- MUST be in Spanish

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model J provides the most comprehensive and well-structured curriculum with 122 chapters covering all aspects from fundamentals to cutting-edge research, career development, and professional skills. The chapter titles are concise (e.g., 'Termodinámica estadística', 'Cinética química') and descriptions are straight to the point without filler words. It includes advanced topics like QM/MM, machine learning, FAIR standards, automation/robotics, and astroquímica. The progression from basic to expert-level is excellent, with proper inclusion of lab techniques, safety, ethics, regulatory compliance, IP/patents, and career guidance. It represents truly top 1% preparation including research methodology, grant writing, and leadership.

Model A offers 69 well-organized chapters covering an impressive breadth from fundamentals through advanced specialized topics. Strong coverage of analytical techniques, computational chemistry, materials science, and professional development. Includes unique topics like 'Roboquímica' (lab automation), forensic chemistry, and scientific leadership. Titles are concise and descriptions appropriately detailed without fluff. The inclusion of research management, funding proposals, and ethics shows preparation for academic leadership. Some descriptions could be slightly more concise but overall excellent quality.

Model C provides 63 chapters with excellent balance between theory and practice. Strong coverage of analytical methods, materials, photochemistry, and supramolecular chemistry. Good inclusion of career guidance, ethics, GLP documentation, and communication skills. Titles are generally concise ('Enlace químico', 'Equilibrio químico'). The descriptions are informative and mostly avoid filler. Includes modern topics like MOFs/COFs, photocatalysis, and sustainability. Slightly less comprehensive than top models in some advanced computational and research management areas.

Model D has 97 chapters with very detailed coverage across all chemistry subdisciplines. Strong progression from fundamentals through advanced topics. Good coverage of professional skills including communication, ethics, IP, and career guidance. Some titles are slightly verbose (e.g., 'Introducción a la química de soluciones acuosas') but generally acceptable. Excellent coverage of bioinorganic, materials, and environmental chemistry. The chapter on 'Herramientas digitales y programación para químicos' is valuable. Minor issue: some chapters could be consolidated for better flow.

Model M provides 99 chapters with impressive depth, especially in organic chemistry and biochemistry. Excellent coverage of spectroscopy, analytical methods, and specialized topics like plasma chemistry and chemistry of extreme conditions. Good inclusion of ethics, project management, and career development. However, some titles are slightly verbose, and there's some repetition between chapters (e.g., multiple atmospheric chemistry chapters). The structure could be slightly better organized but content quality is high.

Model I offers 72 chapters with solid foundational coverage and good progression to advanced topics. Strong in organic chemistry mechanisms and analytical techniques. Includes photochemistry, nanochemistry, green chemistry, and career development. However, titles sometimes use unnecessary words ('Enlace Químico I: Conceptos Básicos' - 'Conceptos Básicos' is redundant). Some advanced research management and computational topics are less developed compared to top models. Good but not exceptional coverage of latest trends.

Model K provides 63 chapters with comprehensive coverage of fundamental through advanced topics. Reasonable balance between subdisciplines. Includes forensics, computational chemistry, and career guidance. However, many titles use capitalization inconsistently and some are verbose ('Equilibrio Ácido-Base' could just be 'Ácidos y bases'). The descriptions sometimes include words like 'Estudio de' which are unnecessary. Coverage of cutting-edge topics and research skills is less thorough than higher-ranked models.

Model G has 55 chapters with good coverage of core chemistry topics. Concise titles ('Tabla periódica', 'Cinética química') are a strength. However, some descriptions are too brief and lack specificity. Missing some important advanced topics like detailed analytical validation, research management, and certain specialized areas. The progression is reasonable but the curriculum seems less complete for truly top-tier preparation. Career section exists but is less developed.

Model B provides 50 chapters covering essential chemistry topics. The coverage is broad but lacks depth in many areas. Many descriptions are quite brief. Missing important topics like detailed spectroscopy interpretation, computational methods beyond basics, and professional skills. 'Electro química' has a typo (should be 'Electroquímica'). Limited coverage of modern trends and research methodology. The curriculum would provide solid intermediate knowledge but falls short of top-tier preparation.

Model L has 52 chapters with decent foundational coverage. However, several titles are verbose ('Fundamentos de la Química y la Materia', 'Medición y Análisis de Datos en Química'). Some descriptions contain filler words ('El Sistema Internacional de Unidades (SI)' in description repeats title content). Limited coverage of advanced computational chemistry, modern analytical techniques, and specialized applications. Career section is present but brief. Does not adequately prepare for top 1% expertise.

Model H provides only 36 chapters, which is insufficient for comprehensive chemistry education. Coverage is too superficial in many areas. Titles like 'Cinetica de las Reacciones' have typos (should be 'Cinética'). Missing many important advanced topics, specialized applications, and professional development content. The brief curriculum would not prepare students for advanced certifications or research leadership. Structure jumps abruptly between topics.

Model E has 41 chapters with basic coverage but inconsistent capitalization in titles (uses Title Case which is not typical Spanish convention). Some titles are verbose ('Química Orgánica I: Fundamentos y Nomenclatura'). The description for 'Fundamentos de Química y Medición' repeats obvious information. Missing detailed coverage of many advanced topics, analytical validation, and research skills. Career development section is present but superficial. Not comprehensive enough for top-tier preparation.

Model F provides only 34 chapters, which is quite limited. Uses inconsistent capitalization (Title Case). Missing many essential advanced topics like detailed organic mechanisms, materials science depth, and research methodology. The coverage would provide intermediate understanding but is insufficient for expert-level preparation. Career section exists but is minimal. Many specialized applications and modern trends are absent.

This model provides the most comprehensive and expert-level curriculum, perfectly aligning with the 'Top 1%' and 'PhD/Leadership' requirements. It explicitly includes essential supporting fields like Mathematics for Chemists and an extensive section on Data Science, Machine Learning, and Programming within Chemistry, which represents the cutting edge of the field. Its professional section is outstanding, covering grant writing, lab leadership, intellectual property, and regulatory compliance in detail. The progression is logical, deep, and covers every requested aspect without fluff.

Model A is an excellent, concise, yet highly advanced curriculum. It distinguishes itself by integrating critical leadership skills such as 'Research Project Management', 'Funding and Proposal Writing', and 'Lab Automation/Robochemistry'. The technical depth is high (covering DFT, advanced spectroscopy), and the titles are perfectly concise. It is a very close second, slightly edged out by Model J's inclusion of a dedicated math foundation and broader data science focus.

Model M offers a very thorough 87-chapter curriculum that covers complex systems, flow chemistry, and extensive biochemical pathways. It addresses the leadership requirement well with chapters on project management and regulatory affairs. It is a strong, modern curriculum, though its structure is slightly more traditional compared to J's heavy emphasis on the computational/data revolution in chemistry.

Model C delivers a solid, well-rounded curriculum that covers all major bases, including a strong section on professional skills (management, ethics, communication). It balances the technical and soft skills well. It ranks below the top three because it is slightly less granular in the advanced emerging trends (like AI/ML or automation) compared to J and A.

This model has a strong industrial and engineering flavor (reactor engineering, process control), which is excellent for the 'leading complex projects' requirement. It is concise and well-structured. However, it feels slightly less comprehensive in the theoretical and computational depth compared to the models ranked above it.

Model D is notable for including specific chapters on digital tools, programming, and intellectual property, which are vital for the target audience. However, the pacing is a bit slow, dedicating a large portion of the early chapters to very basic general chemistry concepts (splitting basics into many chapters), which leaves less room for advanced mastery compared to the higher-ranked models.

Model I is a high-quality academic curriculum, particularly strong in organic and biological chemistry. However, it lacks specific chapters dedicated to the business, leadership, and management aspects of the field (grants, project management) required by the prompt to 'lead complex projects', focusing almost exclusively on technical scientific content.

Model K provides a standard, competent university-level curriculum. It covers the necessary scientific topics well but lacks the 'mastery/expert' edge found in the top models. It misses modern trends like flow chemistry or machine learning and has limited focus on leadership skills.

Model E is decent but somewhat generic. It groups vast topics into single chapters (e.g., 'Química Orgánica I-IV'), which suggests a lack of the granular depth needed for a 'Top 1%' course. The professional skills section is present but basic.

This model is too brief for the stated goals. While the titles are concise, covering the entire field of chemistry to a PhD/Mastery level in just 36 chapters results in superficial coverage of advanced topics.

Model L fails on the specific negative constraint regarding title conciseness (e.g., 'Fundamentos de la Química y la Materia' instead of just 'Materia'). The content is a standard undergraduate overview and does not reach the advanced leadership levels required.
Model B is a basic undergraduate outline. It lacks depth in advanced topics and completely misses the leadership, management, and high-level professional skills required by the prompt.

Model F is the weakest output. It presents a very basic curriculum that would barely satisfy a standard bachelor's degree, failing significantly to meet the 'mastery', 'PhD ready', and 'lead complex projects' expectations.

Cobertura más completa y moderna: desde fundamentos hasta nivel de investigación, incluyendo matemáticas para químicos, metrología/calibración, PAT, ELN/LIMS, automatización/HTE, muestreo mejorado (QM/MM), contaminantes emergentes, LCA y ciencia de datos/ML. Títulos mayormente concisos y sin vendors; descripciones densas y técnicas. Cumple bien el objetivo de preparar para proyectos complejos y estudios avanzados. Único punto débil: es muy largo y algunas secciones (p. ej., forense/cosméticos/astroquímica) pueden sentirse opcionales, pero siguen siendo relevantes para “todo lo necesario”.

Extremadamente amplio y orientado a nivel avanzado/industria/academia: instrumentación, técnicas analíticas, computacional, procesos, regulación (GLP/GMP/ICH), gestión de proyectos, automatización, ML/chemoinformática, etc. Muy alineado con “top 1%”. Debilidad principal: arranca demasiado arriba para principiantes (poca base de medición/estequiometría/gases/soluciones al inicio) y la progresión puede sentirse menos pedagógica; además incluye acrónimos/métodos específicos (HF, MP2, CC) que pueden ser correctos pero elevan la barrera inicial.

Ruta de aprendizaje muy extensa y progresiva, con profundidad notable (flujo continuo, plasma, alta presión, sistemas complejos, química regulatoria, sostenibilidad industrial). Incluye tendencias actuales y temas de frontera. Penaliza por exceso de granularidad y cierto “scope creep” (p. ej., química clínica, cosmética, planetas) que puede dispersar el objetivo central; aun así, es coherente con formación de alto nivel.

Muy fuerte y estructurado: cubre desde cero (mediciones, estructura atómica) hasta temas avanzados (teoría de grupos, estado sólido avanzado, RMN 2D, mecánica estadística, computacional, supramolecular, nano, verde, forense, industrial). Buena progresión y suficiente rigor para posgrado/certificaciones. Le falta más énfasis en tendencias muy recientes (automatización, IA a nivel práctico, PAT, gestión avanzada de proyectos) comparado con los mejores.

Contenido sólido, progresivo y detallado, con buen equilibrio entre fundamentos, orgánica/inorgánica/fisicoquímica/analítica, ingeniería de reactores y habilidades profesionales (literatura, escritura, PI). Incluye herramientas digitales y tendencias emergentes. Baja por ser menos “estado del arte” en IA/automatización y por descripciones a veces largas (algo de ‘fluff’ leve), aunque en general son técnicas.

Muy buen plan integral y moderno: incluye preparación de muestras, validación/calidad, formulación, modelado de procesos, fotoquímica, materiales avanzados, seguridad/GLP/documentación, ética y liderazgo. Buena progresión desde fundamentos. Pierde puntos por no llegar tan lejos en temas de frontera (automatización/HTE, ELN/LIMS, ML más profundo) como J/A y por cierta mezcla de niveles en algunos capítulos intermedios.

Cobertura amplia y bastante completa para grado+; incluye coordinación, organometálica, nano, computacional, fotoquímica, supramolecular, analítica y bioquímica, además de seguridad/ética/comunicación. Sin embargo, queda corto para “maestría/PhD-ready” en tendencias recientes (IA/automatización, prácticas reproducibles avanzadas, gestión de proyectos complejos) y algunas áreas están tratadas de forma más estándar.

Bien estructurado y progresivo para una formación universitaria robusta; incluye analítica instrumental, cuántica, termo estadística, computacional, verde, seguridad, metodología de investigación y carrera. No obstante, es menos profundo y menos actualizado en tendencias (IA aplicada, automatización, datos) y varias descripciones son más explicativas/verbosas de lo pedido.

Cubre fundamentos y varias áreas avanzadas (cuántica, superficies, nano, verde, materiales), pero presenta problemas de concisión y precisión en títulos/terminología: repeticiones y redundancias (p. ej., cromatografía menciona GC y “cromatografía de gases” a la vez), uso de siglas/términos de herramienta en títulos (GC, HPLC, TLC, AAS, ICP), y algunas erratas (“Electro química”, “super conductores”). Menos alineado con la restricción de no usar vendors/herramientas específicas en títulos salvo casos muy establecidos.

Ruta general correcta, pero demasiado genérica para el objetivo de liderazgo en proyectos complejos y preparación tipo posgrado. Varias secciones son amplias y poco técnicas; falta profundidad en analítica avanzada, computacional moderna, gestión de datos/calidad, y tendencias de frontera. Se percibe más como plan de licenciatura básica.

Cobertura aceptable de química general + orgánica/inorgánica/analítica y algo de computacional/industrial. Pero es bastante superficial para el estándar exigido (top 1%, PhD-ready), agrupa en exceso (p. ej., ‘Seguridad y Ética’ en un solo capítulo), no incluye tendencias recientes (IA, automatización, ciencia de datos), y la progresión hacia “maestría” es limitada.

Lista amplia pero con descripciones muy vagas y poco operativas (muchos términos generales sin detalle), lo que no cumple ‘sin fluff’/‘todo lo necesario’. Repite áreas sin un hilo claro (varias de espectroscopia/avanzada) y carece de componentes clave de preparación avanzada (calidad/regulación, reproducibilidad, computación moderna con rigor, gestión de proyectos complejos).

Estructura razonable pero demasiado resumida y con redundancias (química cuántica aparece dos veces; termo avanzada separada sin continuidad clara). Falta profundidad para certificaciones/posgrado y casi no cubre tendencias actuales (IA, automatización, datos, regulatorio avanzado). También hay errores/acentos (“Cinetica”).
